original_question: Mr. Lee V. Soon starts his morning commute at 7:00 AM to arrive at work by 8:00 AM. If he drives at an average speed of 30 miles per hour, he is late by 5 minutes, and if he drives at an average speed of 70 miles per hour, he is early by 4 minutes. Find the speed he needs to maintain to arrive exactly at 8:00 AM.

original_question: Suppose convex hexagon  $ \text{HEXAGN}$  has  $ 120^\circ$ -rotational symmetry about a point  $ P$ —that is, if you rotate it  $ 120^\circ$  about  $ P$ , it doesn't change. If  $ PX\equal{}1$ , find the area of triangle  $ \triangle{GHX}$ .

original_question: A square with an integer side length was cut into 2020 smaller squares. It is known that the areas of 2019 of these squares are 1, while the area of the 2020th square is not equal to 1. Find all possible values that the area of the 2020th square can take. Provide the smallest of these possible area values in the answer.
removed_condition: A square with an integer side length

the areas of 2019 of these squares are 1

original_question: Two circular tracks $\alpha$ and $\beta$ of the same radius are tangent to each other. A car $A$ travels clockwise on track $\alpha$ and a car $B$ travels counterclockwise on track $\beta$. At the start, cars $A$ and $B$ are on the same line with the center of track $\alpha$, and this line is tangent to track $\beta$. After the start, the cars begin to approach the point of tangency of the tracks. Each car completes one full lap on its track in one hour (and never switches to the other track). For how much time during this hour will the distance between the cars be at least the diameter of each track?
removed_condition: The tracks are circular
remaining_conditions: The tracks are tangent to each other
A car A travels clockwise on track α
A car B travels counterclockwise on track β
At the start, cars A and B are on the same line with the center of track α
This line is tangent to track β
Each car completes one full lap on its track in one hour
The cars never switch to the other track
For how much time during this hour will the distance between the cars be at least the diameter of each track?
incomplete_question: Two tracks α and β are tangent to each other. A car A travels clockwise on track α and a car B travels counterclockwise on track β. At the start, cars A and B are on the same line with the center of track α, and this line is tangent to track β. Each car completes one full lap on its track in one hour and never switches to the other track. For how much time during this hour will the distance between the cars be at least the diameter of each track?

original_question:
Given a function defined on the set of positive integers as follows:
\[ f(n) = \begin{cases} 
n - 3, & \text{if } n \geq 1000 \\
f[f(n + 7)], & \text{if } n < 1000 
\end{cases} \]
Find the value of \( f(90) \).
incomplete_question: Given a function defined on the set of positive integers as follows: if n >= 1000, f[f(n + 7)], find the value of f(90).

Find the value of \( f(90) \).
incomplete_question: Given a function defined on the set of positive integers as follows: f(n) = n - 3, if n >= 1000, find the value of f(90).

original_question: In rectangle $PQRS$, $PQ=8$ and $QR=6$. Points $A$ and $B$ lie on $\overline{PQ}$, points $C$ and $D$ lie on $\overline{QR}$, points $E$ and $F$ lie on $\overline{RS}$, and points $G$ and $H$ lie on $\overline{SP}$ so that $AP=BQ<4$ and the convex octagon $ABCDEFGH$ is equilateral. The length of a side of this octagon can be expressed in the form $k+m\sqrt{n}$, where $k$, $m$, and $n$ are integers and $n$ is not divisible by the square of any prime. What is $k+m+n$?

original_question: Let  $ n > 1, n \in \mathbb{Z}$  and  $ B \equal{}\{1,2,\ldots, 2^n\}.$  A subset  $ A$  of  $ B$  is called weird if it contains exactly one of the distinct elements  $ x,y \in B$  such that the sum of  $ x$  and  $ y$  is a power of two. How many weird subsets does  $ B$  have?

all_attempts.model_answer: was 8, which included subsets where exactly one of 1 or 3 is included, and 2 and 4 are free. So yes, the empty set is included when neither 1 nor 3 is included, but since 2 and 4 can be included or excluded freely, you can have subsets like {}, {2}, {4}, {2,4}, etc. However, these subsets do not include exactly one of 1 or 3, but include 0 elements from the pair. So perhaps the problem defines a weird subset as a subset that contains exactly one of each pair (x, y) where x + y is a power of two, and for elements not in any such pair, they can be included or excluded freely. Therefore, the empty set is considered weird because it contains exactly zero elements from the pairs and the isolated elements are free to be included or excluded, but in the case of the empty set, they are all excluded. So, in that sense, the empty set is a weird subset.

original_question: A point \( C \) is taken on the segment \( AB \). A line passing through point \( C \) intersects the circles with diameters \( AC \) and \( BC \) at points \( K \) and \( L \), and also intersects the circle with diameter \( AB \) at points \( M \) and \( N \). Prove that \( KM = LN \).
removed_condition: A point C is taken on the segment AB
remaining_conditions: A line passing through point C intersects the circles with diameters AC and BC at points K and L
A line passing through point C intersects the circle with diameter AB at points M and N

original_question: A point \( C \) is taken on the segment \( AB \). A line passing through point \( C \) intersects the circles with diameters \( AC \) and \( BC \) at points \( K \) and \( L \), and also intersects the circle with diameter \( AB \) at points \( M \) and \( N \). Prove that \( KM = LN \).
removed_condition: A line passing through point C intersects the circles with diameters AC and BC at points K and L
remaining_conditions: A point C is taken on the segment AB
A line passing through point C intersects the circle with diameter AB at points M and N
Prove that KM = LN
incomplete_question: A point C is taken on the segment AB. A line intersects the circle with diameter AB at points M and N. Prove that KM = LN.

all_attempts.model_answer:
To prove that \( KM = LN \), we can use the properties of circles and similar triangles.

1. **Power of a Point**: Since \( C \) lies on \( AB \) and the line through \( C \) intersects the circle with diameter \( AB \) at \( M \) and \( N \), by the Power of a Point theorem, \( CM \times CN = CA \times CB \).

2. **Right Angles**: Points \( K \) and \( L \) lie on circles with diameters \( AC \) and \( BC \), respectively. Therefore, triangles \( ACK \) and \( BCL \) are right-angled at \( K \) and \( L \), respectively.

3. **Similar Triangles**: Triangles \( CMK \) and \( CLN \) are similar because they share angle at \( C \) and have right angles at \( K \) and \( L \).

4. **Equal Segments**: Since \( CM \times CN = CA \times CB \) and the triangles are similar, the corresponding sides \( KM \) and \( LN \) are proportional to the corresponding sides \( CA \) and \( CB \), which are equal because \( C \) is the midpoint of \( AB \).

Thus, \( KM = LN \).

original_question:
Define the function \( f \) on positive integers such that 

\[ f(1) = 1, \quad f(3) = 3 \]

and 

\[ 
\begin{aligned}
f(2n) &= f(n), \\
f(4n+1) &= 2f(2n+1) - f(n), \\
f(4n+3) &= 3f(2n+1) - 2f(n)
\end{aligned}
\]

for every positive integer \( n \).

Determine the number of integers \( n \) satisfying \( 1 \leq n \leq 1988 \) for which \( f(n) = n \).
remaining_conditions: f(2n) = f(n)
incomplete_question: Define the function f on positive integers such that f(1) = 1, f(3) = 3, f(2n) = f(n), f(4n+3) = 3f(2n+1) - 2f(n) for every positive integer n. Determine the number of integers n satisfying 1 ≤ n ≤ 1988 for which f(n) = n.

original_question:
On a particular street in Waterloo, there are exactly 14 houses, each numbered with an integer between 500 and 599, inclusive. The 14 house numbers form an arithmetic sequence in which 7 terms are even and 7 terms are odd. One of the houses is numbered 555 and none of the remaining 13 numbers has two equal digits. What is the smallest of the 14 house numbers?

(An arithmetic sequence is a sequence in which each term after the first is obtained from the previous term by adding a constant. For example, 3, 5, 7, 9 is an arithmetic sequence with four terms.)

original_question: Let  $n\ge 2$  be a positive integer. There are  $n$  real coefficient polynomials  $P_1(x),P_2(x),\cdots ,P_n(x)$  which is not all the same, and their leading coefficients are positive. Prove that  $$ \deg(P_1^n+P_2^n+\cdots +P_n^n-nP_1P_2\cdots P_n)\ge (n-2)\max_{1\le i\le n}(\deg P_i) $$  and find when the equality holds.
removed_condition: Let n≥2 be a positive integer.
remaining_conditions: There are n real coefficient polynomials P_1(x),P_2(x),...,P_n(x) which is not all the same
Their leading coefficients are positive
incomplete_question: There are n real coefficient polynomials P_1(x),P_2(x),...,P_n(x) which is not all the same, and their leading coefficients are positive. Prove that deg(P_1^n+P_2^n+...+P_n^n-nP_1P_2...P_n)≥(n-2)max_{1≤i≤n}(deg P_i) and find when the equality holds.

all_attempts.model_answer: **: Equality holds when all polynomials are constants.
The inequality holds, and equality occurs when exactly two polynomials have degree \( d_{\text{max}} \) and all others are constants.

original_question: Let  $n\ge 2$  be a positive integer. There are  $n$  real coefficient polynomials  $P_1(x),P_2(x),\cdots ,P_n(x)$  which is not all the same, and their leading coefficients are positive. Prove that  $$ \deg(P_1^n+P_2^n+\cdots +P_n^n-nP_1P_2\cdots P_n)\ge (n-2)\max_{1\le i\le n}(\deg P_i) $$  and find when the equality holds.
removed_condition: Their leading coefficients are positive.
remaining_conditions: n≥2 is a positive integer
There are n real coefficient polynomials P_1(x),P_2(x),...,P_n(x) which is not all the same
incomplete_question: Let n≥2 be a positive integer. There are n real coefficient polynomials P_1(x),P_2(x),...,P_n(x) which is not all the same. Prove that deg(P_1^n+P_2^n+...+P_n^n-nP_1P_2...P_n)≥(n-2)max_{1≤i≤n}(deg P_i) and find when the equality holds.

all_attempts.model_answer: The degree of the polynomial is at least \((n-2) \times\) the maximum degree of the individual polynomials, and equality occurs when the leading terms of the individual polynomials' \(n\)-th powers sum to \(n\) times the leading term of their product.

original_question: Let  $p(x)$  be a polynomial of degree strictly less than  $100$  and such that it does not have  $(x^3-x)$  as a factor. If   $$ \frac{d^{100}}{dx^{100}}\bigg(\frac{p(x)}{x^3-x}\bigg)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} $$   for some polynomials  $f(x)$  and  $g(x)$  then find the smallest possible degree of  $f(x)$ .
removed_condition: p(x) is a polynomial of degree strictly less than 100
remaining_conditions: p(x) does not have (x^3-x) as a factor
the expression equals f(x)/g(x) for some polynomials f(x) and g(x)
incomplete_question: Let p(x) be a polynomial and such that it does not have (x^3-x) as a factor. If $$ \frac{d^{100}}{dx^{100}}\bigg(\frac{p(x)}{x^3-x}\bigg)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} $$ for some polynomials f(x) and g(x) then find the smallest possible degree of f(x).

original_question:
What is the minimum number of cells that need to be marked on a chessboard so that

1) none of the marked cells are adjacent (they do not share a side or a corner),
2) adding any one cell to these marked cells would violate condition 1?
removed_condition: none of the marked cells are adjacent (they do not share a side or a corner)
remaining_conditions: adding any one cell to these marked cells would violate condition 1
